definitions: formed into a legal corporation with official registration and status
physically combined or united as part of a whole structure
examples: The newly incorporated company began trading on Monday
Their incorporated business structure provides liability protection
The incorporated design elements blend seamlessly together
These safety features are incorporated into the vehicle frame

definitions: not accurate or true; containing errors or mistakes in facts
not conforming to accepted standards of behavior or protocol
examples: Your answer to the math problem is incorrect
The incorrect information led to serious misunderstandings
His incorrect attire offended the formal dinner guests
Using incorrect etiquette can damage business relationships

definitions: impossible to bribe or morally compromise; having absolute integrity
unable to decay, rot, or decompose; remaining unchanged over time
examples: The incorruptible judge refused all attempts at bribery
Her incorruptible character made her the perfect ethics officer
The ancient texts speak of incorruptible sacred relics
Scientists seek incorruptible materials for deep space missions

definitions: made greater in size, amount, or number than before
made stronger or more intense in degree or effect
examples: The increased budget allows for more research projects
Increased sales figures exceeded all quarterly expectations
Her increased anxiety required immediate medical attention
The increased pressure finally caused the pipe to burst

definitions: becoming greater in size, amount, or number over time
occurring more often or with greater regularity than before
examples: The increasing population strains urban infrastructure
Increasing costs forced the company to raise prices
With increasing frequency, storms batter the coastline
She noticed his increasing absence from team meetings

definitions: so extraordinary as to seem impossible or very difficult to believe
extraordinarily good, wonderful, or impressive in quality or degree
examples: His incredible story of survival defied all logic
The witness gave an incredible account of the events
She has incredible talent as a classical pianist
The view from the mountaintop was absolutely incredible

definitions: unwilling or unable to believe something; showing disbelief
expressing amazement mixed with skepticism or doubt about something
examples: She gave him an incredulous look when he claimed innocence
The jury remained incredulous despite the evidence presented
His incredulous reaction to winning the lottery was priceless
Incredulous laughter filled the room after the announcement

definitions: relating to or denoting gradual increases by regular degrees or additions
characterized by small, measured additions rather than large changes
examples: The company adopted an incremental approach to expansion
Incremental improvements eventually led to breakthrough innovation
Each incremental change brought them closer to their goal
The software uses incremental backups to save storage space

definitions: making someone appear guilty of a crime or wrongdoing
providing evidence that could lead to criminal prosecution or conviction
examples: The incriminating emails proved his involvement in fraud
Police found incriminating evidence at the suspect's home
Her incriminating testimony sealed the defendant's fate
Incriminating documents were discovered during the audit

definitions: currently holding a particular office or position, especially political
necessary as a duty or responsibility; morally binding upon someone
examples: The incumbent president faces a tough reelection campaign
All incumbent senators must defend their voting records
It is incumbent upon us to protect the environment
She felt it incumbent to report the safety violations

definitions: impossible to cure or heal through medical treatment or intervention
impossible to change or reform; persistently maintaining a characteristic
examples: The patient was diagnosed with an incurable disease
Many incurable conditions can still be managed effectively
He's an incurable optimist who sees good in everything
Her incurable habit of arriving late frustrated everyone

definitions: owing money to someone or an institution as a debt
owing gratitude for a service, favor, or benefit received
examples: The heavily indebted company filed for bankruptcy protection
Many students remain indebted for years after graduation
I am deeply indebted to you for your kindness
The author felt indebted to her mentor's guidance

definitions: not conforming to generally accepted standards of morality or propriety
offensive to public standards of decency, especially regarding sexual matters
examples: His indecent behavior at the funeral shocked everyone
The committee found the proposal indecent and rejected it
She was arrested for indecent exposure at the beach
The movie received complaints about indecent content

definitions: unable to make decisions quickly or firmly; hesitant and vacillating
not settling an issue or producing a definite result
examples: The indecisive manager delayed the project for months
She became indecisive when faced with multiple options
The indecisive battle left both armies weakened
After indecisive negotiations, talks were postponed

definitions: persisting tirelessly; showing sustained energetic effort without becoming tired
examples: The indefatigable researcher worked through countless nights
Her indefatigable spirit inspired the entire team
His indefatigable efforts finally paid off with success
The indefatigable volunteers never missed a single day

definitions: not justifiable by argument; impossible to defend morally or logically
impossible to protect against military attack or physical assault
examples: His indefensible actions led to immediate termination
The court found their position legally indefensible
The indefensible outpost was abandoned before dawn
Their indefensible position forced a strategic retreat

definitions: not clearly expressed, defined, or determined; vague or uncertain
lasting for an unknown or unstated length of time
examples: She gave an indefinite answer to avoid commitment
The proposal contains indefinite terms requiring clarification
He took indefinite leave from his position
The project was postponed for an indefinite period

definitions: making marks that cannot be removed, erased, or washed away
not able to be forgotten or removed from memory
examples: The indelible ink stained the white carpet permanently
Voters marked ballots with indelible markers
The tragedy left an indelible mark on the community
Her words made an indelible impression on him

definitions: bound by a legal agreement to work for someone for a specified period
examples: The indentured servants worked for seven years
Indentured laborers built much of colonial infrastructure
The indentured apprentice learned his trade slowly
Many indentured workers eventually gained their freedom

definitions: free from outside control; not subject to another's authority
not depending on others for livelihood or subsistence
not connected with or influenced by something else; separate
examples: The country became independent after years of struggle
Independent nations control their own foreign policy
She's fiercely independent and refuses all help
Independent contractors set their own work schedules
Independent studies confirmed the research findings
These are independent events with no causal relationship

definitions: too extreme, unusual, or indefinite to be adequately described in words
examples: The pain she felt was absolutely indescribable
An indescribable sense of dread filled the room
The sunset's beauty was simply indescribable
He experienced indescribable joy at the reunion

definitions: impossible to destroy or break; extremely durable and resistant to damage
examples: The manufacturer claims these toys are virtually indestructible
Their indestructible friendship survived every challenge
Scientists seek indestructible materials for spacecraft
The ancient fortress seemed indestructible until the earthquake

definitions: not exactly known, established, or defined; uncertain in extent or amount
vague, indefinite, or unclear in character or nature
examples: The fossil's age remains indeterminate without further testing
An indeterminate number of people attended the rally
She gave him an indeterminate smile that puzzled him
The painting's indeterminate style defied classification

definitions: serving as a sign or indication of something; suggestive or symptomatic
denoting a grammatical mood expressing statements of fact
examples: These symptoms are indicative of a serious condition
Her behavior is indicative of underlying stress
Use the indicative mood for factual statements
The indicative form differs from the subjunctive

definitions: liable to be charged with a crime; subject to formal accusation
examples: Murder is an indictable offense requiring jury trial
The prosecutor found several indictable crimes
His actions constitute indictable fraud under federal law
Indictable offenses carry serious potential penalties

definitions: produced, distributed, or created independently from major commercial companies
examples: The indie film won several festival awards
She prefers indie music to mainstream pop
Their indie game became an unexpected hit
The indie bookstore competes with major chains

definitions: having no particular interest or sympathy; unconcerned and unresponsive
neither good nor bad; mediocre or unremarkable in quality
examples: She remained indifferent to his romantic advances
The voters seemed indifferent to the campaign promises
The restaurant serves indifferent food at high prices
His indifferent performance disappointed the director

definitions: originating or occurring naturally in a particular place; native to a region
examples: Indigenous peoples have lived here for thousands of years
The museum displays indigenous art and artifacts
These indigenous plants thrive without special care
Indigenous languages face extinction without preservation efforts

definitions: poor, needy, or lacking sufficient money to live at a standard
examples: The hospital provides free care for indigent patients
Legal aid serves indigent defendants
Many indigent families struggle to afford basic necessities
The charity helps indigent seniors with housing costs

definitions: feeling or showing anger or annoyance at perceived unfair treatment
examples: She was indignant about the false accusations
The crowd grew indignant at the judge's decision
His indignant response surprised everyone present
Indignant protesters gathered outside the courthouse

definitions: having a deep blue color between blue and violet in the spectrum
examples: She wore an elegant indigo dress to the gala
The indigo sky darkened as night approached
Indigo dye has been prized for centuries
The artist mixed indigo paint for the ocean

definitions: not following a straight line or course; roundabout or circuitous
not directly caused by or resulting from something; secondary or implied
examples: We took an indirect route to avoid traffic
The indirect path through the park was scenic
She made indirect references to his past mistakes
Smoking has many indirect health consequences

definitions: done at random or without careful judgment; lacking discrimination or distinction
examples: The indiscriminate bombing killed many civilians
His indiscriminate spending led to bankruptcy
She made indiscriminate accusations against her colleagues
The virus shows indiscriminate infection patterns

definitions: absolutely necessary or essential; too important to be without
examples: Water is indispensable for human survival
She became indispensable to the company's success
His indispensable contributions saved the project
Good communication skills are indispensable in business

definitions: unable to be challenged or denied; unquestionably true or valid
examples: The evidence provides indisputable proof of guilt
Her talent as a pianist is indisputable
These are indisputable facts supported by research
His indisputable authority settled the argument

definitions: not clear or sharply defined; blurred, vague, or difficult to perceive
examples: The indistinct figure disappeared into the fog
Her words became indistinct as she fell asleep
The old photograph showed indistinct faces
Indistinct voices echoed from the next room

definitions: single and separate from others of the same kind or group
characteristic of a particular person; showing unique personal qualities
examples: Each individual case requires careful examination
Individual portions were wrapped in plastic
Her individual style sets her apart from others
The teacher respects individual learning differences

definitions: favoring freedom of action for individuals over collective control
examples: Her individualist philosophy shaped company culture
The individualist approach conflicts with team goals
Individualist societies emphasize personal achievement
His individualist attitude alienated potential allies

definitions: characterized by individualism; prioritizing individual needs over group needs
examples: The individualistic culture values personal freedom highly
Her individualistic approach ignored team dynamics
Individualistic behavior can disrupt group harmony
Western societies tend toward individualistic values

definitions: modified or designed to meet individual requirements or characteristics
examples: Students receive individualized instruction based on needs
The gym offers individualized training programs
Individualized medicine considers genetic differences
Each client gets individualized attention and care

definitions: unable to be divided or separated into parts; forming an inseparable whole
examples: They believe the nation is indivisible despite differences
The concept treats mind and body as indivisible
Liberty and justice are indivisible principles
The indivisible atom was once scientific dogma

definitions: impossible to subdue or defeat; having unconquerable determination or spirit
examples: Her indomitable spirit carried her through illness
The team's indomitable will led to victory
He faced challenges with indomitable courage
The indomitable fortress withstood every siege

definitions: situated, conducted, or used within a building or under cover
examples: The indoor pool stays open year-round
We moved the party indoor when it rained
Indoor plants need different care than outdoor varieties
The mall features an indoor skating rink

definitions: brought about or caused artificially rather than occurring naturally
examples: The doctor performed a medically induced delivery
Drug-induced hallucinations affected his testimony
The experiment studied induced mutations in fruit flies
Stress-induced illness forced her to take leave

definitions: characterized by reasoning from particular facts to general principles
examples: Scientists use inductive reasoning to form hypotheses
The inductive method builds theories from observations
Her inductive approach started with concrete examples
Inductive arguments suggest probable conclusions

definitions: readily giving in to someone's wishes; excessively generous or lenient
allowing oneself or others to enjoy pleasure or luxury
examples: The indulgent parents never disciplined their children
His indulgent attitude toward mistakes frustrated colleagues
She enjoyed an indulgent spa weekend
The indulgent dessert menu tempted every diner

definitions: relating to or characterized by industry and manufacturing activities
examples: The industrial revolution transformed society
Industrial waste pollutes nearby rivers
This industrial area employs thousands of workers
They use industrial-strength cleaning products

definitions: having developed industries and advanced manufacturing as economic basis
examples: Industrialised nations dominate global trade
The newly industrialised country attracted foreign investment
Industrialised farming methods increase crop yields
Their industrialised society values efficiency

definitions: having developed industries and advanced manufacturing as economic basis
examples: Industrialized countries face new economic challenges
The region became industrialized during the twentieth century
Industrialized agriculture relies on modern machinery
Most industrialized nations have service economies

definitions: diligent and hardworking; showing dedication to work and effort
examples: The industrious student completed extra assignments
Her industrious nature impressed every employer
Industrious workers built the railroad in record time
The industrious bees collected nectar all day
